inventory.commentary: 22jan07 - modified features of Senses 2 and 3 to clarify the distinction. ahouston

sense.name: an innate ability, mental or physical
sense.examples: The author has possesses a great faculty for philosophical analysis. Her grandmother's mental faculties have not diminished with age. John has a faculty for saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. The faculty of smell is much more developed in dogs than in humans.

sense.name: professors in an academic institution
sense.commentary: FACULTY[+entity][+social][+group][+people][+teacher][+school][+university/+high_school] Note: refers to -people-, not to institutions (see Sense 3)
sense.examples: He's on the faculty at Princeton. There were few tenured women on the faculty during that era. Many of the faculty and students have signed the petition.

sense.name: a branch of a university
sense.commentary: FACULTY[+entity][+social][+institution][+educational][+department][+academic] Note: refers to a department, part of an academic institution, -not- the teachers (see Sense 2) Note: almost always of the form 'faculty of X' where X is an institution.
sense.examples: John is the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at a major university. Mary received her diploma from the faculty of engineering.

sense.name: power or authority that is conferred
sense.commentary: FACULTY[+state][+authority][+conferred] Note: often refers to an authorization given by a religious group.
sense.examples: The church granted him the faculty to perform an exorcism on the child. They stripped him of the faculty to perform mass.
